p: All essential oils showed poor antibacterial activity in comparison with the antibiotic chloramphenicol, however differences could be observed among the EOs and bacterial strains ( Table 3). For example, all EOs were less effective against S. pneumoniae TIGR4 in comparison with S. pneumoniae D39. For S. pneumoniae TIGR 4, tea tree EO showed better activity than Myrtaceae EOs, and the strain was even resistant to Ed EO. For H. influenzae, no significant differences ( p > 0.05) were observed between the antibacterial activity-assayed Myrtaceae EOs ( Table 3).
